StudyObjective: To examine the brain mechanisms involved in gradually learning and subsequently generalizing a set of visual discriminations, particularly exploring whether hippocampal and/or neocortical activity at encoding, retrieval, or both, was associated with generalizations between equivalence classes.

fMRITasks.TaskName: Visual Discrimination Learning and Generalization Task
fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Participants learned a set of visual discriminations via trial-and-error (learning phase) and were subsequently tested on their ability to generalize what they had learned (generalization phase) within a first-person virtual reality environment.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: The task consisted of a learning phase followed by a generalization phase, both occurring within a single scanning session. Each trial presented a scene with two buildings, one concealing a reward. Participants had 3 seconds to select the rewarded building, followed by 7 seconds of video feedback and a 1-second intertrial interval. There were 48 trials per discrimination presented in a pseudorandom order, with 12 test trials in the generalization phase.
TaskMetrics: Binary sequences indicating correct versus incorrect responses
fMRITasks.TaskDuration: Single scanning session including learning and generalization phases.
